title: Comparing the individual effects of metformin and rosiglitazone and their combination in obese women with polycystic ovary syndrome: a randomized controlled trial
authors: Yujing Li, Jing Tan, Qiuyi Wang, Changling Duan, Yuanyuan Hu, Wei Huang
abstract: High-dose metformin (1,500 mg/day) is most effective for weight loss in obese PCOS patients with insulin resistance, while rosiglitazone users show greater improvements in cholesterol and triglyceride levels.

title: Association of maternal polycystic ovary syndrome and diabetes with preterm birth and offspring birth size: a population-based cohort study
authors: Xinxia Chen, Mika Gissler, Catharina Lavebratt
abstract: Women with PCOS have significantly higher risks of total and spontaneous preterm birth when they also have non-insulin-treated type 2 diabetes or gestational diabetes, based on analysis of over 1 million births in Finland.

title: Investigation of the Association of Serum Trace Elements Concentrations and Serum Biochemical Parameters with the Risk of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome: a Case-Control Study
authors: Priya Sharma, Harmanpreet Singh Kapoor, Balpreet Kaur, Pooja Kamra, Preeti Khetarpal
abstract: Multiple serum trace elements (copper, magnesium, selenium, iron, chromium, and manganese, but not zinc) and biochemical parameters including cholesterol, CRP, and albumin are significantly associated with PCOS risk in a case-control study of 99 PCOS patients and 82 controls.

title: A randomized controlled trial of combination letrozole and clomiphene citrate or letrozole alone for ovulation induction in women with polycystic ovary syndrome
authors: Rachel B Mejia, Karen M Summers, Jessica D Kresowik, Bradley J Van Voorhis
abstract: Combination therapy of letrozole and clomiphene citrate results in significantly higher ovulation rates (77% vs. 43%) compared to letrozole alone in infertile women with PCOS.

title: Alterations in Gut Microbiome Composition and Barrier Function Are Associated with Reproductive and Metabolic Defects in Women with Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS): A Pilot Study
authors: Lisa Lindheim, Mina Bashir, Julia Münzker, Christian Trummer, Verena Zachhuber, Bettina Leber, Angela Horvath, Thomas R Pieber, Gregor Gorkiewicz, Vanessa Stadlbauer, Barbara Obermayer-Pietsch
abstract: PCOS patients have significantly lower gut microbiome diversity and altered phylogenetic composition compared to healthy controls, with specific bacterial families associated with reproductive parameters.

title: A randomized, controlled trial comparing the metformin, oral contraceptive pills and their combination in patients with polycystic ovarian syndrome
authors: Yogesh Kumar, Narendra Kotwal, Yashpal Singh, Vimal Upreti, Shrikant Somani, K V S Hari Kumar
journal: Journal of Family Medicine and Primary Care
abstract: Combination therapy with metformin and oral contraceptive pills shows superior results in reducing inflammatory markers, insulin resistance, and improving body composition compared to either drug alone in 90 PCOS patients.

title: Therapeutic effects of metformin and clomiphene in combination with lifestyle intervention on infertility in women with obese polycystic ovary syndrome
authors: Jing Zhang, Qinqin Si, Jinqiong Li
abstract: Lifestyle adjustment combined with metformin and clomiphene significantly improves menstrual recovery, ovulation rates, and pregnancy rates in 101 infertile women with obese PCOS compared to medication alone.

title: Evaluating the effect of insulin sensitizers metformin and pioglitazone alone and in combination on women with polycystic ovary syndrome: An RCT
authors: Seyed Mojtaba Sohrevardi, Fahime Nosouhi, Saeed Hossein Khalilzade, Parichehr Kafaie, Mojgan Karimi-Zarchi, Iman Halvaei, Mehdi Mohsenzadeh
abstract: Both metformin and pioglitazone improve insulin resistance and menstrual cyclicity in 84 PCOS women, but only metformin significantly reduces hyperandrogenemia while pioglitazone increases body weight.

title: Effects of metformin alone and in combination with spironolactone on hyperandrogenism in polycystic ovarian syndrome
authors: Nasser K. Abd Elaal, Hamed E. Ellakwa, Alaa Eldeen F. El Halaby, Shaza S. Maklad
abstract: Adding low-dose spironolactone to metformin produces significantly greater reductions in free testosterone and clinical hyperandrogenism compared to metformin alone in 48 PCOS patients over 6 months.

title: Analysis on endocrine and metabolic features of different phenotypes of polycystic ovary syndrome patients
authors: Feng Li, Li Yao, Hong Wu, Shihong Cao
abstract: Analysis of 226 PCOS patients shows four distinct phenotypes with different endocrine and metabolic profiles, with the anovulation plus polycystic ovary phenotype being most common (55.8%) and phenotype classification guiding individualized treatment.

title: Neurokinin B Receptor Antagonism in Women With Polycystic Ovary Syndrome: A Randomized, Placebo-Controlled Trial
authors: Jyothis T. George, Rahul Kakkar, Jayne Marshall, Martin L. Scott, Richard D. Finkelman, Tony W. Ho, Johannes Veldhuis, Karolina Skorupskaite, Richard A. Anderson, Stuart McIntosh, Lorraine Webber
journal: The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism
abstract: The neurokinin-3 receptor antagonist AZD4901 (80 mg/day) significantly reduces LH pulse frequency by 52%, LH levels, and testosterone concentrations by 28.7% in 65 women with PCOS, presenting a novel targeted treatment approach.

title: Increased COVID-19 infections in women with polycystic ovary syndrome: a population-based study
authors: Anuradhaa Subramanian, Astha Anand, Nicola J Adderley, Kelvin Okoth, Konstantinos A Toulis, Krishna Gokhale, Christopher Sainsbury, Michael W O'Reilly, Wiebke Arlt, Krishnarajah Nirantharakumar
abstract: Women with PCOS have a 28% increased risk of COVID-19 infection (adjusted HR 1.28) in a UK population study of 21,292 PCOS women and 78,310 matched controls, independent of BMI and other risk factors.

title: Childhood, adolescent, and adulthood adiposity are associated with risk of PCOS: a Mendelian randomization study with meta-analysis
authors: Laurence J Dobbie, Bradley Pittam, Sizheng Steven Zhao, Uazman Alam, Theresa J Hydes, Thomas M Barber, Daniel J Cuthbertson
abstract: Mendelian randomization analysis reveals that excess body fat during childhood, adolescence, and adulthood independently and linearly increases PCOS risk, with childhood body size showing an independent effect (OR 2.56) even after adjusting for adult body size.

title: Randomized Controlled Trial of Preconception Interventions in Infertile Women With Polycystic Ovary Syndrome
authors: Richard S. Legro, William C. Dodson, Penny M. Kris-Etherton, Allen R. Kunselman, Christy M. Stetter, Nancy I. Williams, Carol L. Gnatuk, Stephanie J. Estes, Jennifer Fleming, Kelly C. Allison, David B. Sarwer, Christos Coutifaris, Anuja Dokras
journal: The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism
abstract: Preconception weight loss interventions (lifestyle modification with or without OCPs) achieve 6.2-6.4% weight loss, eliminate adverse metabolic effects of OCPs, and lead to superior ovulation rates (60-67% vs. 46% with OCPs alone) in 149 overweight/obese PCOS women.

title: Sexual dysfunction in women with PCOS: a case control study
authors: H Pastoor, M C Timman, W L D M Nelen, A Bos-Roubos, J S E Laven, R van Dreven, W L J M Schoonderwoerd-Rooijackers, J M M van Lith, C B Lambalk, E A F Dancet, C Weiss, A M H Brandenbarg, K G H Wiersema, B W Mol, C T Brouwer
abstract: Women with PCOS report significantly higher rates of sexual dysfunction (41.2% vs. 11.9%) and sexual distress (51.5% vs. 19.4%) compared to controls in a case-control study of 135 women, with minimal association to androgen levels.

title: Global, regional, and national burden of infertility attributable to PCOS, 1990–2019
authors: Yilei Dong, Qiqi Cai, Jiajun Du, Chengxi Li, Wenfeng Song, Jie Kang, Lihua Duan
abstract: Global analysis of 204 countries from 1990-2019 reveals the burden of PCOS-attributable infertility increased sharply, with highest rates in high SDI regions and greatest annual increases in middle and low-middle SDI regions.

title: Prevalence and phenotypic features of polycystic ovary syndrome: a systematic review and meta-analysis
authors: Gurkan Bozdag, Sezcan Mumusoglu, Defne Zengin, Engin Karabulut, Bulent Okan Yildiz
abstract: Systematic review and meta-analysis of 55 reports shows PCOS prevalence varies by diagnostic criteria: NIH 6% (5-8%), Rotterdam 10% (8-13%), and AE-PCOS Society 10% (7-13%) in general populations.

title: Moderate increases in daily step count are associated with reduced IL6 and CRP in women with PCOS
authors: M A Webb, H Mani, S J Robertson, H L Waller, D R Webb, C L Edwardson, D H Bodicoat, T Yates, K Khunti, M J Davies
abstract: Modest increases of 1000 steps per day are associated with 13% reductions in both IL6 and CRP inflammatory markers in 65 women with PCOS over 6 months, potentially reducing future diabetes and cardiovascular disease risk.

title: Characteristic gut microbiota and predicted metabolic functions in women with PCOS
authors: Liang Zhou, Zhexin Ni, Wei Cheng, Jiahui Yu, Sun Sun, Dan Zhai, Chaoqin Yu, Zhuo Cai
abstract: High-throughput 16S rRNA gene sequencing of 101 women reveals that obese and non-obese PCOS patients have distinct characteristic gut microbiota (Coprococcus_2 in obese, Lactococcus in non-obese) with differences in predicted metabolic functions.

title: Androgens impair β-cell function in a mouse model of polycystic ovary syndrome by activating endoplasmic reticulum stress
authors: Weiying Zhang, Jia Xu, Jing Bian, Chun Xu, Jiao Xu, Yi Chen, Dandan Zhao, Danhua Lu, Chunmei Liang
abstract: Androgen excess in a DHEA-induced PCOS mouse model impairs β-cell function through activation of endoplasmic reticulum stress, which can be reversed by blocking this pathway to improve insulin homeostasis and reduce hyperinsulinemia.

title: Changes in clinical and biochemical characteristics of polycystic ovary syndrome with advancing age
authors: Sebastião Freitas de Medeiros, Matheus Antônio Souto de Medeiros, Márcia Marly Winck Yamamoto, Jacklyne Silva Barbosa, José Maria Soares Júnior
abstract: Cross-sectional study of 796 PCOS and 444 control women shows that serum androgen levels decrease with aging in PCOS but remain elevated compared to controls, while carbohydrate markers, triglycerides, and cholesterol tend to worsen over time.

title: Adrenal hyperandrogenism does not deteriorate insulin resistance and lipid profile in women with PCOS
authors: Ilias Moustakli, Konstantinos Dafopoulos, Alexandros Sotiriou, Efstratios Kolibianakis, Dimitrios G Goulis, Basil C Tarlatzis
abstract: Study of 372 PCOS women shows that the presence of adrenal hyperandrogenism (elevated DHEA-S) does not worsen metabolic parameters including insulin resistance and lipid profile, and may even prevent further metabolic deterioration.

title: Reproductive and metabolic features during puberty in sons of women with polycystic ovary syndrome
authors: Nicolás Crisosto, Barbara Echiburú, Manuel Maliqueo, Marta Luchsinger, Pedro Rojas, Sergio Recabarren, Teresa Sir-Petermann
abstract: Sons of women with PCOS show increased total cholesterol and LDL levels during puberty compared to controls (69 PCOS sons vs. 84 control sons), suggesting latent insulin resistance and future cardiovascular risk that requires monitoring.

title: Polycystic ovary syndrome and risk factors for gestational diabetes
authors: Terhi Piltonen, Laure Morin-Papunen, Riitta Koivunen, Sari Ruokonen, Jouko Tapanainen, Eila Pesonen
abstract: FinnGeDi multicentre study of 1,146 GDM women and 1,066 controls shows PCOS is not an independent risk factor for gestational diabetes, with increased GDM risk in PCOS women mainly related to obesity rather than PCOS itself.

title: Trends, Predictors, and Outcomes of Cardiovascular Complications Associated With Polycystic Ovary Syndrome During Delivery Hospitalizations: A National Inpatient Sample Analysis (2002-2019)
authors: Salman Zahid, Muhammad Zia Khan, Smitha Gowda, Nadeen N. Faza, Michael C. Honigberg, Arthur Jason Vaught, Carolyn Guan, Anum S. Minhas, Erin D. Michos
journal: Journal of the American Heart Association
abstract: National Inpatient Sample analysis of 71.4 million delivery hospitalizations (2002-2019) shows PCOS is an independent predictor of cardiovascular complications including preeclampsia (aOR 1.56), eclampsia (aOR 1.58), peripartum cardiomyopathy (aOR 1.79), and heart failure (aOR 1.76).

title: Association between polycystic ovary syndrome and hot flash presentation during the midlife period
authors: Ophelia Yin, Howard A. Zacur, Jodi A. Flaws, Mindy S. Christianson
abstract: Midlife Women's Health Study of 453 women aged 45-54 (42 with PCOS, 411 controls) shows history of PCOS is not associated with increased hot flash symptoms during the midlife/menopausal period, with smoking being the only significant predictor.

title: A Hyperandrogenic Mouse Model to Study Polycystic Ovary Syndrome
authors: Ping Xue, Zhiqiang Wang, Xiaomin Fu, Junjiang Wang, Gopika Punchhi, Andrew Wolfe, Sheng Wu
abstract: Protocol describes a lean hyperandrogenic PCOS mouse model using monthly-replaced DHT crystal pellets that produces 2-fold elevated DHT levels, reproductive and metabolic dysfunction without weight changes, and transgenerational effects in offspring.

title: Insulin signaling displayed a differential tissue-specific response to low-dose dihydrotestosterone in female mice
authors: Stanley Andrisse, Katelyn Billings, Ping Xue, Sheng Wu
journal: American Journal of Physiology - Endocrinology and Metabolism
abstract: Low-dose DHT in female mice demonstrates tissue-specific differential effects on insulin signaling, with impaired signaling in liver and adipose tissue but enhanced or unchanged signaling in ovaries and pituitaries, independent of hyperinsulinemia.

title: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of the Association Between Polycystic Ovary Syndrome and Coronary Artery Calcification
authors: Olatokunbo Osibogun, Oluseye Ogunmoroti, Olamide B. Kolade, Allison G. Hays, Victor Okunrintemi, Anum S. Minhas, Martha Gulati, Erin D. Michos
abstract: Systematic review and meta-analysis of 7 studies with 2,341 participants shows women with PCOS have approximately twofold greater odds of coronary artery calcification (pooled aOR 2.48 for cohort studies, 1.88 for cross-sectional studies) compared to women without PCOS.

title: Androgen-induced insulin resistance is ameliorated by deletion of hepatic androgen receptor in females
authors: Stanley Andrisse, Mingxiao Feng, Zhiqiang Wang, Olubusayo Awe, Lexiang Yu, Haiying Zhang, Sheng Bi, Hongbing Wang, Linhao Li, Serene Joseph, Nicola Heller, Franck Mauvais-Jarvis, Guang William Wong, James Segars, Andrew Wolfe, Sara Divall, Rexford Ahima, Sheng Wu
abstract: Female mice with hepatic androgen receptor deletion (LivARKO) are protected from DHT-induced glucose intolerance, insulin resistance, and metabolic dysfunction, demonstrating that elevated androgens disrupt female metabolic function specifically through hepatic androgen receptor signaling.

title: The Role of Lifestyle Interventions in PCOS Management: A Systematic Review
authors: Gautam R, Maan P, Jyoti A, Kumar A, Malhotra N, Arora T
abstract: Dietary interventions including low-GI foods, caloric restriction, omega-3 diets, ketogenic diets, Mediterranean diets, and anti-inflammatory diets improve insulin sensitivity and hormonal balance in women with PCOS; physical activity enhances insulin sensitivity and weight loss.

title: The overlooked mental health burden of polycystic ovary syndrome: neurobiological insights into PCOS-related depression
authors: Dubé-Zinatelli E, Anderson F, Ismail N
abstract: Women with PCOS face heightened risk of depression due to dysregulation in endocrine and immune systems and gut microbiome disturbances; symptoms like infertility, obesity, and hirsutism cause psychological distress that exacerbates depression.

title: The prevalence and risk of anxiety and depression in polycystic ovary syndrome: an overview of systematic reviews with meta-analysis
authors: Abdul Jafar NK, Al Balushi A, Subramanian A, Lee SI, Bennett CJ, Moran LJ, Mousa A, Tay CT, Teede HJ, Mansfield DR
abstract: Anxiety symptoms were highly prevalent in PCOS (prevalence varied by questionnaire: Hamilton Anxiety Scale 69.4%, HADS 41.5%); depression symptoms were most prevalent using Beck Depression Inventory (46.0%); PCOS women had higher risk of anxiety and depression than controls.

title: Polycystic ovary syndrome and mental disorders: a systematic review and exploratory meta-analysis
authors: Cooney LG, Lee I, Sammel MD, Dokras A
abstract: Women with PCOS had higher rates of anxiety (OR 2.76, 95% CI 1.26-6.02) and depressive symptoms (OR 3.51, 95% CI 1.97-6.24) compared to women without PCOS; anxiety and depression are more prevalent in PCOS patients.

title: Analysis of risk factors for depression and anxiety in women with polycystic ovary syndrome
authors: Yang Y, Liu L, Hu N, Huo H, Yang X, Wang F
abstract: Depression and anxiety prevalence in PCOS was 47.7% and 39.9% respectively; depression was significantly associated with serum FT3, sleep duration, and daytime dysfunction; anxiety was associated with daytime dysfunction.

title: PCOS Physiopathology and Vitamin D Deficiency: Biological Insights and Perspectives for Treatment
authors: Lerchbaum E, Rabe T
abstract: Women with PCOS are deficient in vitamin D, particularly those with higher weight; hypovitaminosis is a risk factor for glucose intolerance and associated with insulin resistance and increased diabetes risk; vitamin D supplementation improved glucose homeostasis and hormonal status.

title: Vitamin D and polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS): a review
authors: Thakur D, Kaur A
journal: Journal of Family Medicine and Primary Care
abstract: 67-85% of PCOS women have vitamin D deficiency; low vitamin D levels exacerbate PCOS symptoms including insulin resistance, menstrual irregularities, infertility, hyperandrogenism, and obesity; vitamin D supplementation may improve symptoms.

title: Vitamin D deficiency is common and associated with metabolic risk factors in patients with polycystic ovary syndrome
authors: Li HW, Brereton RE, Anderson RA, Wallace AM, Ho CK
journal: BJOG: An International Journal of Obstetrics & Gynaecology
abstract: 44.0% of PCOS women had severe vitamin D deficiency vs 11.2% of controls (p=0.047); vitamin D concentrations negatively correlated with BMI, C-reactive protein, and free androgen index and positively correlated with insulin sensitivity and HDL-C.

title: Resistance and aerobic training increases genome-wide DNA methylation in women with polycystic ovary syndrome
authors: Vieira Neto L, Medeiros SF, Norman RJ
abstract: Both resistance and aerobic exercise improved anthropometric indices, metabolic dysfunction, and hyperandrogenism in PCOS after 16 weeks; exercise increased genome-wide DNA methylation which may relate to metabolic and hormonal changes and promote health and longevity.

title: Exercise Interventions in Polycystic Ovary Syndrome: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
authors: Dos Santos IK, Ashe MC, Cobucci RN, Soares GM, de Oliveira Maranhão TM, Dantas PMS
abstract: Aerobic exercise of various intensities consistently improved VO2peak in PCOS; moderate intensity exercise improved waist circumference and BMI when combined with diet; resistance training showed promising improvements in free androgen index and insulin resistance.

title: A Systematic Review of the Effects of Exercise on Hormones in Women with Polycystic Ovary Syndrome
authors: Jiskoot G, Dietz de Loos A, Beerthuizen A, Timman R, Busschbach J, Laven J
abstract: Vigorous aerobic exercise and resistance training improve insulin sensitivity and androgen levels in PCOS; recommended guidelines include both exercise types; resistance training may improve androgen levels though additional studies are warranted.

title: The effects of different exercises on weight loss and hormonal changes in women with polycystic ovarian syndrome: a network meta-analysis study
authors: Hajizadeh F, Fathollahi-Shourabeh F, Moezy A, Salesi M
abstract: Moderate-intensity aerobic exercise is most effective for reducing BMI in PCOS compared to no intervention and yoga; other forms of exercise were ineffective for weight loss; exercise had no significant impact on sex hormones or menstrual regularity.

title: Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome Genetics and Epigenetics
authors: Chen ZJ, Zhao H, He L, Shi Y, Qin Y, Shi Y, Li Z, You L, Zhao J, Liu J, Liang X, Zhao X, Zhao J, Sun Y, Zhang B, Jiang H, Zhao D, Bian Y, Gao X, Geng L, Li Y, Zhu D, Sun X, Xu JE, Hao C, Ren CE, Zhang Y, Chen S, Zhang W, Yang A, Yan J, Li Y, Ma J, Zhao Y
abstract: PCOS is a complex disorder with heritable genetics suspected due to familial clustering; genome-wide DNA methylation and microRNA patterns may improve diagnosis accuracy; mitochondrial DNA variants contribute to inflammation and insulin resistance.

title: Epigenetic inheritance of PCOS by developmental programming and germline transmission
authors: Stener-Victorin E, Padmanabhan V, Walters KA, Campbell RE, Benrick A, Giacobini P, Dumesic DA, Abbott DH
abstract: Emerging research suggests potential transgenerational inheritance of PCOS through genetic and epigenetic mechanisms; PCOS-related risks may affect subsequent generations including sons; developmental programming plays a key role.

title: Epigenetic inheritance of polycystic ovary syndrome - challenges and opportunities for treatment
authors: Stener-Victorin E, Deng Q
abstract: Genetic loci account for only 10% of PCOS heritability (estimated at 70%); altered epigenetic and developmental programming from maternal uterine environment contributes to pathogenesis; PCOS-like traits are transgenerationally inherited up to F3 generation.

title: Genetic Basis of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS): Current Perspectives
authors: Escobar-Morreale HF
abstract: PCOS is a polygenic and multifactorial disorder with complex pathophysiology involving multiple pathways and proteins; epigenetic changes are transgenerationally heritable; increased fetal androgen exposure causes epigenetic changes contributing to PCOS development.

title: PCOS and genetics: Exploring the heterogeneous role of potential genes in ovarian dysfunction, a hallmark of PCOS
authors: Nishanthini J, Kandasamy S, Bose Vijay K, Balamurugan K
abstract: Key genes involved in ovarian dysfunction in PCOS include CYP11A1, CYP17A1, CYP19A1, AR, FSHR, LHCGR, AMH, INSR, SHBG, IRS1, GATA4, ADIPOQ, YAP1, TCF7L2, and DENND1A; epigenetic factors and miRNAs also play critical roles.

title: Increased prevalence of obstructive sleep apnea syndrome in obese women with polycystic ovary syndrome
authors: Vgontzas AN, Legro RS, Bixler EO, Grayev A, Kales A, Chrousos GP
abstract: Obese PCOS women had higher apnea-hypopnea index (22.5 vs 6.7, p=0.008) and were more likely to have symptomatic OSA syndrome (44.4% vs 5.5%, p=0.008); AHI correlated with waist-hip ratio, testosterone, and unbound testosterone.

title: Obstructive sleep apnea syndrome in polycystic ovary syndrome: a systematic review and meta-analysis
authors: Abdul Jafar NK, Al Balushi A, Subramanian A, Lee SI, Bennett CJ, Moran LJ, Mousa A, Tay CT, Teede HJ, Mansfield DR
abstract: PCOS is associated with high prevalence of obstructive sleep apnea; prevalence ranged 17-75% in PCOS vs general population; OSA is associated with obesity, insulin resistance, gestational diabetes, type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and impaired quality of life.

title: Polycystic ovary syndrome is associated with obstructive sleep apnea and daytime sleepiness: role of insulin resistance
authors: Vgontzas AN, Legro RS, Bixler EO, Grayev A, Kales A, Chrousos GP
abstract: PCOS patients were 30 times more likely to have sleep disordered breathing than controls (OR 30.6, 95% CI 7.2-139.4); insulin resistance is a stronger risk factor than BMI or testosterone for sleep apnea in PCOS.

title: Polycystic ovary syndrome and the risk of obstructive sleep apnea: a meta-analysis and review of the literature
authors: Kahal H, Kyrou I, Tahrani AA, Randeva HS
abstract: Pooled OSA prevalence was 22% in PCOS patients (32% in adults, 8% in adolescents); risk of OSA was significantly increased in adult PCOS patients (OR 9.74, 95% CI 2.76-34.41).

title: Pathogenesis and Consequences of Disordered Sleep in PCOS
authors: Sam S, Ehrmann DA
abstract: Sleep disturbances are increased in PCOS women; obstructive sleep apnea is the most commonly reported; OSA leads to increased sympathetic tone and oxidative stress which worsens insulin resistance in PCOS, creating a vicious cycle.

title: Update on the combination of myo-inositol/d-chiro-inositol for the treatment of polycystic ovary syndrome
authors: Unfer V, Facchinetti F, Orru B, Giordani B, Nestler J
abstract: Combination of myo-inositol and D-chiro-inositol addresses insulin resistance and ovarian dysfunction in PCOS; myo-inositol improves FSH signaling and oocyte quality while D-chiro-inositol aids insulin-mediated androgen synthesis regulation.

title: The inositols and polycystic ovary syndrome
authors: Kalra B, Kalra S, Sharma JB
journal: Indian Journal of Endocrinology and Metabolism
abstract: Combination myo-inositol and D-chiro-inositol therapy corrects systemic insulin resistance and creates healthy intra-ovarian milieu; addresses metabolic features, hyperandrogenism, menstrual regularity, ovulation and fertility in PCOS.

title: Myo-inositol effects in women with PCOS: a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials
authors: Unfer V, Nestler JE, Kamenov ZA, Prapas N, Facchinetti F
abstract: Myo-inositol supplementation significantly decreased fasting insulin (SMD -1.021 µU/mL, p=0.009) and HOMA index (SMD -0.585, p=0.041); showed trend toward testosterone reduction; SHBG increased significantly with ≥24 weeks treatment.

title: Inositol for Polycystic Ovary Syndrome: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis to Inform the 2023 Update of the International Evidence-based PCOS Guidelines
authors: Fitz V, Teede HJ, Brennan L, Moran LJ
abstract: Evidence suggests benefits for myo-inositol or D-chiro-inositol for some metabolic measures and potential benefits from DCI for ovulation; myo-inositol likely causes fewer gastrointestinal adverse events compared with metformin.

title: PCOS and Inositols: Controversial Results and Necessary Clarifications. Basic Differences Between D-Chiro and Myo-Inositol
authors: Monastra G, Vucenik I, Harrath AH, Alwasel SH, Kamenov ZA, Laganà AS, Monti N, Fedeli V, Bizzarri M
abstract: Myo-inositol and D-chiro-inositol display opposite effects on ovary and steroidogenesis despite both improving insulin transduction; D-chiro-inositol directly regulates steroidogenic enzyme genes and increases testosterone levels in theca cells; high doses of D-chiro-inositol can be detrimental.

title: Are women with PCOS more at risk for endometrial cancer? What approach for such patients?
authors: Gullo G, Scaglione M, Buzzaccarini G, Laganà AS, Basile G, Chiantera V, Török P, Herman T, Unfer V, Garzon S
abstract: Risk of endometrial cancer is 2-6 times higher in PCOS women; increased prevalence associated with chronic anovulation and progesterone resistance; age and endometrial thickness are important predictors; routine screening not indicated but high-risk women should be monitored closely.

title: Polycystic ovary syndrome is associated with a higher risk of premalignant and malignant endometrial polyps in premenopausal women
authors: Zhu Y, Zhang W, Zhao Y, Li C, Hu Y
abstract: Prevalence of premalignant and malignant endometrial polyps was 2.15% (hyperplasia with atypia 1.13%, endometrial carcinoma 1.02%); PCOS was associated with higher risk of premalignant and malignant polyps after adjustment for confounding factors.

title: Risk of endometrial cancer in patients with polycystic ovarian syndrome: A meta-analysis
authors: Dumesic DA, Padmanabhan V, Chazenbalk GD, Abbott DH
abstract: Women with PCOS had significantly increased odds of developing endometrial cancer (OR 4.07, 95% CI 2.13-7.78); when postmenopausal subjects excluded, odds increased to 5.14; PCOS patients are up to 5 times more likely to develop endometrial cancer.

title: Association between polycystic ovarian syndrome and endometrial, ovarian, and breast cancer: A population-based cohort study in Taiwan
authors: Hsu MI, Chen HF, Hwu YM, Tsai SJ, Wu MY, Chang CH, Kuo TC, Chen TC, Kuo PH, Ho HN
abstract: Incidence of endometrial cancer was 226 per 100,000 person-years in PCOS vs 15 in comparison group; significantly higher risk (aHR 17.7, 95% CI 4.9-64.2); no association found between PCOS and ovarian or breast cancer.

title: Clinical and psychological correlates of quality-of-life in polycystic ovary syndrome
authors: Elsenbruch S, Hahn S, Kowalsky D, Öffner AH, Schedlowski M, Mann K, Janssen OE
abstract: PCOS patients showed significant reductions in quality of life, increased psychological disturbances, and decreased sexual satisfaction; BMI and hirsutism scores were associated with physical aspects of quality of life and sexual satisfaction.

title: Health-related quality of life and psychological distress in polycystic ovary syndrome: a hidden facet in South Asian women
authors: Kumarapeli V, Seneviratne Rde A, Wijeyaratne CN, Yapa RM, Dodampahala SH
journal: BJOG: An International Journal of Obstetrics & Gynaecology
abstract: Mean GHQ score was significantly higher in PCOS (5.25±6.25) than controls (1.58±1.46); hirsutism was significantly associated with psychological distress; mean scores for physical, psychological and social relationships domains were significantly lower in PCOS.

title: Quality of life and psychological well being in polycystic ovary syndrome
authors: Coffey S, Bano G, Mason HD
abstract: 71% of PCOS women taking anti-androgen medication and 67% not taking medication were classified as depressed; women with PCOS had lower quality of life on all seven factors; weight was largest contributor to poor quality of life.

title: Quality of life and psychological morbidity in women with polycystic ovary syndrome: body mass index, age and the provision of patient information are significant modifiers
authors: Jones GL, Benes K, Clark TL, Denham R, Holder MG, Haynes TJ, Mulgrew NC, Shepherd KE, Wilkinson VH, Singh M, Balen AH, Lashen H, Ledger WL
abstract: SF-36 scores were significantly lower than age- and sex-matched population; GHQ-28 identified psychological morbidity in 62.4% vs 26.4% in matched population; BMI was negatively correlated with quality of life; positive association between psychological domain and quality of health information.

title: Measures of health-related quality of life in PCOS women: a systematic review
authors: Behboodi Moghadam Z, Fereidooni B, Saffari M, Montazeri A
abstract: 52 studies reviewed; various generic and specific questionnaires assess different dimensions of HRQoL; weight concerns have particular negative impact on HRQoL though role of BMI is inconclusive; psychological dimensions more affected than physical dimensions.

title: Impact of polycystic ovary syndrome on quality of life of women in correlation to age, basal metabolic index, education and marriage
authors: Bhattacharya SM, Ghosh M
abstract: PCOS cases showed significantly decreased HRQoL compared to controls; increased BMI, menstrual irregularities, educational status and marital status play major role in altering HRQoL; psychological care must be given during patient management.
